SUMMARY: transcription factor RbsR, for Ribose Repressor, is negatively autoregulated and controls transcription of operon involved in ribose catabolism and transport [1304369, 6327616, 11750821]. Transcription of this operon is induced when E. coli is grown in absence of glucose and when physiological inducer D-ribose binds to RbsR repressor [11750821, 3011793]. When D-ribose binds to RbsR, protein becomes inactive because binding affinity of RbsR decreases [1304369]. RbsR represses not only rbs operon for transport and utilization of D-ribose but also de novo synsis of purine nucleotides from D-ribose 5-phosphate. In presence of inducer D-ribose, RbsR activates salvage pathway of purine nucleotide synsis [23651393]. Although little is known about mechanism of regulation of RbsR transcription factor, Mauzy et al. in 1992 demonstrated that this regulator acts as a repressor by binding to cis-acting elements, which have a conserved inverted repeat sequence and overlap rbsD promoter [1304369]. RbsR belongs to GalR/LacI family, which forms a bundle of four helices characteristic of proteins of an HTH DNA contact motif. C-terminal 270 residues of RbsR are homologous to ribose-binding protein RbsB.
